questions.text: Match the following anesthetic agents with respect to their side effects.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1.Propofol - Oil in a water emulsion.It contains EGG LECITHIN (not protein),hence,It is safe in egg allergy. 2.Fentanyl-causes stimulation of frontal cortex,leading to muscle contraction of truncal muscles,resulting in rigid/wooden chest syndrome. 3.Midazolam-causes suppression of vasomotor centers resulting in hypotension. 4.Nitric oxide-causes pulmonary vasoconstriction,resulting in pulmonary hypertension. 5.Dissociative anesthesia is a S/E of ketamine. 6.Adrenal insufficiency is a S/E of etomidate.

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high pressure oxygen through nasal cannula:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) delivers very high flows of O2 [2 to 40 L/min]This is the newest technique of O2 delivery (in adults) using heated [37°C] and humidified gas. Using oxygen that is heated to body temperature and supersaturated with water (to a relative humidity of 99%), O2 flow rates up to 40–60 L/min can be delivered through wide nasal prongs without discomfort and mucosal injury. Physiological dead space washout of waste gases including carbon dioxide (CO2) i.e,It causes displacement of excess CO2 with excess O2.It Decrease work of breathing by decreasing airway resistance through the application of a positive pressure.It provides a Positive end-expiratory pressure(PEEP). Option C-It can decrease the need of intubation,which is a disadvantage,as we'll end up intubating the patient in a very late stage resulting in significant morbidity and mortality.

choices.text: Patient with 7 pack years of smoking

questions.text: Pulmonary complications are seen/expected in all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-BMI>30 i.e, obese are at risk of Pulmonary complications. Option B-Upper abdominal surgery causes a splinting effect on breathing resulting in basal atelectasis of lungs. Option C-Patient with 40 pack years of smoking are at risk of Pulmonary complications. Option D-Patients with Age > 70 are at risk of Pulmonary complications.

questions.text: arrange in sequence the following steps of intubation : A. Head extension and neck flexion B. Introduction of laryngoscope C. Inflation of cuff D. Check breath sounds with stethoscope
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Steps of intubation are:- A. Head extension and neck flexion. B. Introduction of laryngoscope and then introduce ETT. C. Inflation of cuff Of ETT with air. D. Check breath sounds with stethoscope.

questions.text: Post OP every day they used to give 3 mg morphine epidurally and one day they gave 12 mg mistakenly. which was not the expected side effect due to this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Complications of epidural opioids include:- Option A,B,C-Dose dependant effects of epidural opioids are: Respiratory Depression(hence,needing Oxygen with NIV) , Nausea and Vomiting And Urinary Retention. Option D-Dose independent effect of epidural opioids is Pruritis.Best answer here will itching as it wont be expected to increase due to increase in dose of epidural morphine. Rest all complications will be increased.

questions.text: Tramadol and its metabolite acts by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Tramadol is a weak opioid which acts by 5HT and NE reuptake inhibition,hence it is SNRI(serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor). Option B-Tramadol do not cause dopamine reuptake inhibition. Option C,D-Anticholinergic and Antihistaminic properties are seen in TCAs.

choices.text: To increase heart rate to acceptable level
To decrease the risk of aspiration

questions.text: Purpose of giving glycopyrrolate before GA is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Glycopyrrolate is not used to increase heart rate to acceptable level. Option B-To decrease the risk of aspiration,we use drugs like PPIs,which decreases gastric acid production. Option C-Glycopyrrolate is not used to maintain blood pressure. Option D-Glycopyrrolate is an Anti cholinergic drug.It is a Premedication i.e, all the drugs that are given to the patient before induction.It decreases respiratory secretions due to its Anti cholinergic action.

choices.text: To generate anesthesia and muscle relaxation

questions.text: Reason for giving sodium thiopentone and iv succinylcholine during ECT is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the induction of a generalised seizure by electrical stimulation of one or both cerebral hemispheres. Drugs used in ECT are:- Induction agents: methohexital (gold standard) > etomidate (max decrease in seizure threshold) > ketamine (anti-depressant) > thiopentone > propofol Muscle relaxant: Scoline > Mivacurium. Hence,sodium thiopentone and iv succinylcholine is given to generate anesthesia and muscle relaxation respectively.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Gate Control Theory of Pain is a mechanism, in the spinal cord in which pain signals can be sent up to the brain to be processed to accentuate the possible perceived pain, or attenuate it at the spinal cord itself. The 'gate' is the mechanism where pain signals can be let through or restricted. One of two things can happen, the gate can be 'open' or the gate can be 'closed': If the gate is open, pain signals can pass through and will be sent to the brain to perceive the pain. If the gate is closed, pain signals will be restricted from travelling up to the brain, and the sensation of pain won't be perceived. If someone experiences a painful (noxious) stimulus, the application of a non-noxious (soothing or light rubbing or Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) stimulus can help activate the gate control mechanism, and reduce the pain.

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about initial setting?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Select an inspiratory flow rate of 60 L/min if the patient is breathing quietly or has no spontaneous respirations.Use higher inspiratory flow rates (e.g. 80 L/min) for patients with respiratory distress. Option B-Set the initial PEEP to 5 cm H2O to prevent the collapse of distal airspaces at end expiration. Option C-Select an initial tidal volume of 8 mL/kg using predicted body weight and Reduce the tidal volume to 6 mL/kg over the next 2 hours, if possible. Option D-Keep Fio2 =100% in the initial hours.

questions.text: What is shown in the following image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given image shows multiple handles of laryngoscope,hence it is related to airway.Therefore, It is a difficult airway cart.

questions.text: Identify the gas (arrow) in the image shown?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pipeline colour coding system is:- Option A-Oxygen -blue/white Option B-Nitrous oxide -blue Option C-Air -grey/white. Option D-Suction- yellow

questions.text: Identify the device?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) The newest technique of O2 delivery (in adults) is high-flow nasal O2 using heated and humidified gas. Using oxygen that is heated to body temperature and supersaturated with water (to a relative humidity of 99%),FIO2 (21–100%), O2 flow rates up to 40–60 L/min can be delivered through wide nasal prongs without discomfort and mucosal injury. Decrease work of breathing by decreasing airway resistance through the application of a positive pressure Provides Positive end-expiratory pressure

questions.text: What are the components of high quality CPR ? A: Chest compressions at 100-120 per min B: ventilation 22-25 per min C: allow adequate recoil D: Upto 5-6 cms depth in adult
questions.solution: Correct Answer(D)

questions.text: Arrange the correct sequence of steps in Basic Life Support (CPR) as per latest guidelines: a) check pulse & respiration b) call for help c) assess responsiveness d) start chest compressions e) start bag and mask
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sequence: c) Assess responsiveness • The first step is always to check if the person is responsive. Shout at them and shake them gently to assess if they are conscious. If they don’t respond, move to the next step. b) Call for help • Immediately call emergency services (or ask someone to do so). This step should be done right after checking for responsiveness to ensure help is on the way. a) Check pulse & respiration • Check for signs of life (pulse and breathing). This should be done as quickly as possible after calling for help. If there is no pulse and no breathing (or abnormal breathing like gasping), proceed to the next step. d) Start chest compressions • Start chest compressions immediately: 30 compressions at a depth of 2 inches (5 cm) at a rate of 100-120 per minute. Compressions are the priority to circulate oxygenated blood to vital organs. e) Start bag and mask (or rescue breaths) • After 30 compressions, if you're trained, provide 2 rescue breaths using a bag-mask or mouth-to-mouth. If you’re untrained, continue compressions only until professional help arrives or an AED is available.

choices.text: Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

questions.text: Mechanism of Action of local anaesthetics is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B-local anaesthetics do not Decreasing K or Ca efflux. Option C-RMP of cell is not changed on giving -local anaesthetics. Option D-local anaesthetics Binds to sodium channels, causing their inactivation.As a result,nerve won't be depolarised and hence,Patient won't feel the pain.

questions.text: Most common cause of admission after day care surgery is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Day care surgery means admission, operation and discharge in the same day.Do not keep patient overnight in hospital. Option A-Bleeding can be a cause,but it is not the most common cause. Option B,D-2nd most common cause is complications associated with opioid use for pain i.e respiratory complications and post operative nausea and vomiting. Option C-Pain is the most common cause of unplanned hospital admission after day care surgery.

questions.text: Maximum FiO2 is delivered by which device?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Venturi mask-24-50% Option B-Hudson mask-35-50% Option C-Nasal cannula-24-40% Option D-Non rebreathing mask-60-80%

questions.text: Identify the reading:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Capnography is a measure of End Tidal CO2 [ETCO2] concentration in mm Hg along with its graphical representation. Capnography is one of the essential monitors during anesthesia especially general anesthesia and is an indicator of both respiration and circulation during anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sole high potency inhaled anesthetic agent that can be used for both induction and endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inhaled anesthetic agent that can be used for induction and endotracheal intubation,should be sweet smelling,which are Sevoflurane and halothane. Out of these,sevoflurane is preferred because of favourable hemodynamic and anesthetic characteristics and faster onset.

questions.text: 20 % Intralipid bolus was administered during resuscitation. Why?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Treatment of local anesthetic systemic toxicity [LAST]: LATE & GRAVE TOXICITY due to local anesthetics is cardio toxicity. • Most cardiotoxic LA - BUPIVACAINE [highly lipid soluble- doesn't dissociate from Na+ channels]. • Drug of choice for LAST is infusion of 20% INTRALIPID solution: bolus dose : 1.5 ml/kg followed by infusion of 0.25 ml \kg\min • Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac bupivacaine concentration. • No other antiarrhythmic is useful. • Use of lignocaine is not recommended. • 2 drugs useful are adrenaline and amiodarone as per ACLS guidelines for the management of cardiac arrest • Later in severe cases, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) can be used.

questions.text: Maximum flow rate of oxygen that can be used by conventional oxygen therapy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Conventional oxygen therapy (COT) is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation and has conventionally been delivered using nasal prongs, cannula or masks. However, the maximal oxygen flow rates that these devices can deliver are limited. The maximal oxygen flow rate delivered by COT is only 15 L/min, which is far lower than the demands of post extubation patients with acute respiratory failure. Furthermore, with oxygen delivered by COT, it is difficult to meet the requirements of heating and humidification in these patients. High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can supply a mixture of air and oxygen via a heated and humidified circuit at a very high flow. It can provide almost pure oxygen with a FiO2 of approximately 100% and a maximal flow rate up to 60 L/min. The use of a HFNC may generate a positive airway pressure, ameliorate oxygenation and dyspnoea, reduce the respiratory rate and work of breathing, and improve comfort.

questions.text: ASA 1 patient posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During surgery, sudden drop in ETCO2 to 8 mm hg with hypotension and tachycardia but airway pressures were 18 cm H20. What’s the diagnosis? 1) CO2 embolism 2) Pneumothorax 3) bronchospasm 4) single bronchus intubation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1.For laparoscopy, you need to create a pneumoperitoneum,for which the gas used is CO2. SUDDEN DROP OF ETCO2 WITH HYPOTENSION AND TACHYCARDIA WITH NORMAL AIRWAY PRESSURE : CO2 embolism 2.Pneumothorax- will not cause drop in ETCO2 but it'll cause very high airway pressure as one lung is collapsed by pneumothorax. 3.Bronchospasm- airway pressure will not be normal,it will be increased 4.Single bronchus intubation: fall in ETCO2 will not be there.

questions.text: What is the frequency of stimulus in tetanic stimulation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) PTC (post-tetanic count) is a neuromuscular monitoring mode that allows the anesthesia care team to assess deep neuromuscular blockade when the TOF Count is 0. In the PTC mode, 50 Hz stimulation is applied for 5 seconds to enhance the neuromuscular junction's response to stimuli.

questions.text: While exercising and on reaching equilibrium state, it was found that body was consuming 1500 ml/min of oxygen. Calculate MET score if baseline at rest O2 consumption is 250 ml/min
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) One metabolic equivalent of task (MET) is the amount of oxygen consumed while sitting at rest, and is equivalent to an oxygen consumption of 3.5 mL/min/kg body weight. Since his body was consuming-1500ml/min. and his O2 consumption at rest is 250 ml/min. So,his MET will be:-1500/250=6 MET. >4 METs : adequate functional capacity from cardiac point of view.

questions.text: If you want to get venous access below this specific bone, what will be the complication?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-The immediate complications of subclavian vein cannulation include puncture of the subclavian artery (5%), pneumothorax (5%), brachial plexus injury (3%), and phrenic nerve injury (1.5%). Option B-Venous access below clavicle :- supraclavicular approach to a subclavian vein. In the given image,we're getting venous access on left side. Left-sided internal jugular or subclavian access carries a higher risk of lymphatic injury due to the anatomic location of the thoracic duct, but lymphatic injury can still occur with right-sided access.Hence, Chylothorax is a specific answer in this question. Option C,D-Empyema and Thrombophlebitis can also occur.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of potency of anesthetic agents?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Higher the value of MAC, lesser is the potency. POTENCY:It is defined as the minimum alveolar concentration of anesthetic at 1 atmosphere (atm), which produces immobility in 50% of subjects exposed to a noxious stimulus, usually a skin incision. INCREASING ORDER OF MAC\DECREASING ORDER OF POTENCY:- • HALOTHANE < ISOFLURANE< SEVOFLURANE < DESFLURANE < XENON < NITROUS OXIDE. • LOWEST MAC\ HIGHEST POTENCY: METHOXYFLURANE

questions.text: Person is under surgery for laryngeal malignancy, while ligating jugular vein, he suddenly developed hypotension ,ventricular arrhythmia and sudden fall in ETC02 . which of the following could have caused this effect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common complication of Sitting position surgery is venous air embolism. Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture and risk factors present like Large central vein open to air,Sudden drop of ETC02 while manipulating the large vein,Head and neck surgery where the position of the patient is kept head up so the vein is above the level of the heart. The venous air embolism results in hypotension ,ventricular arrhythmia and sudden fall in ETC02 .

questions.text: A patient who came to the emergency with acute pancreatitis was shifted to ICU and intubated. The ventilator settings are: FiO2 90%, PEEP 12, RR 16. An arterial blood gas analysis showed PaO2 110 mmHg and PaCO2 58mmHg and SaO2 is 100%. What would be the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Pancreatitis is a known cause of ARDS, hence lung protective ventilation is required.FiO2 100% (titrate to 60% or lower as soon as possible).Hence,In this patient, reduction of FiO2 will be the next step. Option B-Respiratory rate is kept 14-16/min. Option C-PEEP of 5 to 10 cm H20. Option D-Low tidal volume ventilation is given in these patients. Tidal volume is maintained at 6-8ml/kg,

questions.text: Which of the following test is depicted in the given image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Allen’s test is done to check the collateral blood supply between the radial and the ulnar artery. A negative Allen test means that the patient likely does not have an adequate dual blood supply to the hand, which may present a contraindication to the planned procedure like ABG. Option B,C-Roos test,also known as Elevated arm stress test is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome. Option D-Adson's sign or Adson's maneuver is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome. The clinician has the patient extend their neck and turn their head to the side that is being tested. The patient then holds their breath and the radial pulse is palpated.

choices.text: Depth of chest compressions is 5 to 6cm

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about CPR?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CPR is started when there is no pulse and no breathing. High Quality chest compressions include:- Option A-Push fast (100-120/min) Option B-Adequate ventilation (RR-10/min). Option C-Push hard (5-6cm depth) Option D-Allow complete chest recoil and Minimum interruptions in chest compression

choices.text: Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous baby
Suctioning of mouth and nose after shoulder delivery in non-vigorous baby

questions.text: True for meconium stained liquor management is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous baby is done. Endotracheal suctioning is not recommended anymore for non-vigorous, meconium stained baby. Meconium stained babies are managed the same as non-vigorous, clear amniotic fluid babies.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy reported to emergency with breathing difficulty. Monitor was attached and the following graph was seen on capnography.The diagnosis can be:- 1. Pericarditis 2. Acute bronchial asthma 3. Cardiac tamponade 4. Bronchospasm
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given capnogram shows a sharkfin pattern, which is typical of Asthma or COPD or bronchospasm. This shape is due to the abnormal plateau phase, representing limited expiration which may be caused by increased airway resistance and possible bronchospasm or other obstruction of exhalation.

questions.text: A central line was inserted for total parenteral nutrition. All of the following complications may be seen except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Aspiration can not occur in parenteral nutrition as food is not passing through the orogastric route. Option B,C,D-Complications seen after central line insertion are- Infection,Pneumothorax due to injury to lung and Refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: In a patient with thrombocytopenia, in order to proceed with surgery platelet transfusion is done to achieve a platelet level of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The minimum platelet count to proceed with surgery is 50,000.

questions.text: Identify a 2nd generation supraglottic airway device?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There are broadly two types of Supraglottic airway device:- first generation (classic LMA, Unique, AuraOnce, AuraStraight). second generation (e.g. i-Gel, LMA Pro-Seal, LMA-Supreme, AuraGain). The main difference between the two being is that the second generation has a gastric lumen that allows for drainage of gastric fluids or secretions.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for fast reversal of rocuronium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Neostigmine can also be used,but it is not specifically used for rocuronium. Option B-Sugammadex is a medication used for the rapid reversal of neuromuscular blockade induced by rocuronium or vecuronium during surgery. It works by encapsulating the muscle relaxant molecule, effectively reversing its effects and allowing the patient to regain muscle function quickly. Option C,D-Edrophonium and Glycopyrrolate are not used commonly for reversal.

questions.text: What are the components of quality CPR in adults? A. Compression rate 100-120/min B. Depth in adults 3-4 cm C. ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions D. Allow recoil
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The 5 Components of High Quality CPR :- • Depth: 2–2.4 inches (5–6 centimeters) • Compression rate: 100–120/minute. • Recoil: Allow for full recoil after each compression. • Minimize pauses in compressions. • Ventilation: 2 breaths after 30 compressions without an advanced airway; 1 breath every 6 seconds with an advanced airway.

questions.text: Which inhaled aesthetic agent is used for pediatric induction\anesthesia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Sevoflurane is preferred for pediatric patients undergoing induction by inhalation because of its low propensity to cause respiratory irritation . It is commonly used in children because of sweet odor and rapid induction and recovery of anesthesia. Option B-Desflurane is pungent,therefore, not used. Option C-Isoflurane is not commonly used for induction. Option D-Halothane is also weet smelling,but sevoflurane is preferred because of its rapid onset.

choices.text: Severe illness which is life threatening.

questions.text: Correct about ASA-3 class is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ASA classification is as follows:- 1-A person in good health. 2-A mild but well-managed or treated condition. 3-A serious condition that has an impact on a person’s overall health. 4-A severe condition that’s life-threatening. 5-A life-threatening condition that needs immediate surgery to increase survival odds. 6-A deceased person who is an organ donor.

questions.text: FIO2 DELIVERED BY NASAL CANNULA FOR A 5-YEAR-OLD CHILD AT 3 LITRES\ MIN?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) FIO2 DELIVERED BY NASAL CANNULA FOR A 5-YEAR-OLD CHILD AT 3 LITRES\ MIN is 35%.

questions.text: AMBU AURA 40 IS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2ND GENERATION LMA The AMBU Aura 40 is classified as a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA). Unlike first-generation LMAs, which lack advanced features like gastric access or reinforced tubing, second-generation LMAs such as the Aura 40 incorporate improvements like a preformed curved stem for easier insertion, a softer cuff for better sealing, and enhanced safety features to reduce the risk of airway obstruction. However, it does not have a dedicated gastric drainage channel, which is a hallmark of third-generation LMAs (e.g., LMA ProSeal or LMA Supreme). The AMBU Aura series is designed for single use and is widely utilized in anesthesia for its reliability and ease of placement, making it a standard second-generation LMA option in clinical practice.

questions.text: WHICH DRUG SHOWS ADRENAL GLAND SUPPRESSION?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-SCOLINE causes masseter spasm. Option B-PROPOFOL can cause propofol infusion syndrome if given in high doses for prolonged duration. Option C-ETOMIDATE causes inhibition of 11-hydroxylase enzyme resulting in adrenal insufficiency. Option D-KETAMINE causes dissociative anesthesia.

questions.text: THERE IS A PATIENT WITH FRACTURE OF 3RD TO 8TH RIB AND ISN'T HAVING SUFFICIENT PAIN RELIEF WITH SYSTEMIC ANALGESICS. WHAT WOULD BE THE BEST NEXT COURSE OF MANAGEMENT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-SUPRACLAVICULAR BRACHIAL PLEXUS BLOCK is given for relief of pain in upper limb. Option B-CERVICAL PLEXUS BLOCK is given for relief of pain in neck. Option C-LUMBAR EPIDURAL BLOCK is given for relief of pain in lower limb. Option D-THORACIC EPIDURAL BLOCK is given for relief of pain in thoracic region,as given in question.

choices.text: CHEST COMPRESSION SHOULD BE ONE THIRD THE AP DIAMETER OF CHEST
COMPRESSION TO VENTILATION RATIO IS 30:2 WITH 2 RESCUER
ADENOSINE IS PREFFERED DRUG BY INTRAOSSEOUS ROUTE
ADRENALINE IS USED AS 0.01 MG\KG IN A 1:1000 DILUTION

questions.text: Regarding Pediatrics resuscitation, which is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In pediatric resuscitation, the depth of chest compressions is crucial for effective cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). Current guidelines, such as those from the American Heart Association (AHA) and European Resuscitation Council (ERC), recommend that chest compressions should be at least one-third the anterior-posterior (AP) diameter of the chest for both infants and children. This depth ensures adequate compression of the heart to generate blood flow without causing excessive injury. Therefore, option (A) is the correct statement. Let's look at why the other options are incorrect: B. COMPRESSION TO VENTILATION RATIO IS 30:2 WITH 2 RESCUER: This statement is incorrect for pediatric resuscitation with two rescuers. For single-rescuer pediatric CPR, the ratio is indeed 30 compressions to 2 ventilations. However, when two or more rescuers are present for pediatric CPR, the recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations. This higher compression rate aims to minimize interruptions in chest compressions. C. ADENOSINE IS PREFERRED DRUG BY INTRAOSSEOUS ROUTE: While adenosine can be administered via the intraosseous (IO) route, it is typically used for the treatment of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), not as a general preferred drug for resuscitation in cardiac arrest. The primary drugs for pediatric cardiac arrest are adrenaline (epinephrine), and other medications are given based on the specific rhythm. The choice of route (IV or IO) depends on vascular access availability, but adenosine itself is not the "preferred drug" in the broad context of pediatric resuscitation. D. ADRENALINE IS USED AS 0.01 MG/KG IN A 1:1000 DILUTION: This statement is partially incorrect. The recommended dose of adrenaline (epinephrine) for pediatric cardiac arrest is indeed 0.01 mg/kg. However, this dose is given as a 1:10,000 dilution, not 1:1,000. Using a 1:1,000 dilution at 0.01 mg/kg would result in a dose ten times higher than recommended, which can be dangerous. The 1:1,000 dilution is typically used for intramuscular administration in anaphylaxis, not for intravenous/intraosseous administration in cardiac arrest.

questions.text: JR CIRCUIT IS USED FOR?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) JR CIRCUIT (Jackson and reese modification of Ayre's T-piece) is used for pediatric patients.

choices.text: RENAL CLEARANCE IS HIGH AND THAT IS THE REASON FOR FAST TERMINATION OF ACTION
THIOPENTONE IS GIVEN AS SLOW IV INJECTION.
THIOPENTONE GETS REDISTRIBUTED IN ADIPOSE TISSUES

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS AN INCORRECT STATEMENT ABOUT THIOPENTONE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-RENAL CLEARANCE IS HIGH AND THAT IS THE REASON FOR FAST TERMINATION OF ACTION is a wrong statement.As redistribution of thiopentone is the reason for it's rapid termination of action. Option B-IT HAS HIGH LIPID SOLUBILITY is a true statement. Option C-THIOPENTONE IS GIVEN AS SLOW IV INJECTION TO PREVENT RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION. Option D-THIOPENTONE GETS REDISTRIBUTED IN ADIPOSE TISSUES DUE TO ITS HIGH LIPID SOLUBILITY.

questions.text: In a child with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), what should NOT be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer(A)

questions.solution: Correct Answer(B)

questions.text: During femoral artery catheterization, a local anesthetic is injected below the inguinal ligament. Which nerve is primarily blocked?
questions.solution: Correct Answer(B)

Induction and muscle relaxant given simultaneously to facilitate intubation
Preoxygenation for 3 min with tidal volume breathing

questions.text: Regarding Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI), all are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer(A)

questions.solution: Correct Answer(B)

questions.text: for benzodiazepine and barbiturates which are true? A: both act on GABA B: cause additive sedation with alcohol C: thiopentone has short duration of action due to metabolism D: flumazenil is antidote for barbiturates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)
